headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Kal Penn is Interviewed about Biden's Poll Numbers and His Show; Navy Searches for Spy Balloon Debris; Beyonce Makes History. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: As the 2024 presidential election approaches, where's the enthusiasm? This as Biden gets ready to deliver the State of the Union Address tomorrow night. A new "Washington Post"/ABC News poll finds only 36 percent of voters believe Biden has accomplished a great or good deal, 62 percent think he's accomplished not much or little.Let's talk big picture here with former White House aide under President Obama, Kal Penn, who you'll also, you know, recognize him from movies and TV.

utterances.speaker: KAL PENN, FORMER OBAMA WHITE HOUSE AIDE
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You got it. He is the host of the new "Bloomberg" series, "Getting Warmer with Kal Penn."

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Part of the reason I'm sleepy this morning, from watching him.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Oh, yes, it's great.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Well, thanks for watching.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We'll get to that - your new show in a moment.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because it's actually really important to, to the, you know, the future of the planet and stuff.But, let's -

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: We try.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about 2024. So, you were there in the trenches in the Obama White House.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What do you make of these numbers? It even has independents more in Trump's camp than Biden's camp.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes, look, polls will always fluctuate. It's so far from the 2024 election. I think what's exciting for folks like me and a lot of others is, you know, Biden's the most progressive president we've had. This climate bill, for example, you know, that took decades of advocacy from a lot of people, especially a lot of young people who aren't necessarily young anymore.And so one of the great challenges - and I felt this when I was President Obama's youth liaison is, young people are the only demographic that don't stay with their demographic over a lifetime. Obviously, you age out.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: So, any of the advocacy you do when you're 18 or 22, that comes to fruition when you're in your 30s, you don't necessarily feel that joy and that ownership, but that's exactly what's happening. And so I think telling that story and letting folks know, look, things are not a light switch. Change doesn't happen overnight. It's a really slow build. I think that's a really positive thing for the Biden administration.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But why do you think he's not getting more credit for that? Because, you know, you talk about the investments from the Inflation Reduction Act. But "The Washington Post" poll, it's 62 percent of people think he's accomplished not very much or little during his time in office.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Well, what have they done in their lives?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But is it like a - is it like a selling problem or like -

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just kidding. But, yes, I don't know. Look, I, again, poll -- one of my first bosses when I worked in organizing in Iowa in 2007 was Paul Toos (ph).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: And he basically kept saying, polls don't mean anything. He used more colorful language than that. But it's true, right? It's the idea that polls are very immediate. It's a very specific type of group that they're polling. I don't know how these polls work, but back in the day they would still only call land lines, right?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You're right. You're right about all of it.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: So, I don't know how to respond to those numbers. All I know is, between now and when the 2024 election is, is an eternity. And I think the president and the administration are doing a great job.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The only real poll -- someone who said - I forget who said it -- is at the ballot box, right?

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The polls.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The actual when you go to the polls to vote.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes, also, I mean, look at the last several election cycles, right? Neither Obama nor Trump would have necessarily won if they hadn't successfully expanded the electorate. And none of that would have shown up in polls.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Or Biden. Biden has defied expectations. He's never going to -

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: That's it. Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You know, you saw what South Carolina did for him. He's never going to win.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Or, he's never going to get bipartisan support. I was very critical of him saying, what is he doing? He should have learned during Obama that the Republicans don't want to work with him.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Did you say it just like that?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And now - yes, just like that, because back then I was younger and my voice was a little higher. But -- and now Republicans are working with him and he's facing very tough opposition from Republicans and still getting things done.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But can we talk about you?

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Always.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Because this is about Kal Penn. Kal Penn - "Getting Warm with Kal Penn" on Bloomberg about climate and clean energy. This is a clip that I watched last night. It's about plastics. We're going to play it and then we'll talk to you about it.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: We take a look at a problem we're unlikely to recycle our way out of, plastic.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The perception out there is, what I put in my recycling bin, you know, the blue bin -

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Is what technically can be recycled. But in the reality, no recycling company anywhere is mandated by law to recycle what you put in the blue bin. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALEhelping corporations reassure us about things we should not be reassured about. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, a very real moment for that related to -

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Because we have these separation bins in our -- you know, you pull out, and you put the plastic and cardboard on that side and whatever.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And then you take -- and you don't know what happens to it.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: My mom, who's from Louisiana, she's like, what are you guys doing? Like, why do you have things on different - like, she didn't get it.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, the stats are staggering. Less than 6 percent of plastic waste is recycled in the U.S. And you point out that putting stuff in recycle bins doesn't mean that it gets recycled. So, what is going on. Mom is right! She doesn't even know.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: See, your mom is not wrong, it's -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: So, one of the things that I certainly didn't know about in hosting this show, you know, the take, as you mentioned, it's a positive, optimistic take on climate change solutions rather than the doom and gloom stuff.That said, one of the big challenges with especially plastic recycling, recycling in general, the difference between what's municipally recyclable, meaning what you can actually toss in the garbage that's collected at home from the town or the city is different than what companies say things are recyclable, meaning, a lot of companies will say, OK, this toothpaste tube or this pen is technically recyclable, but it's not, because the cost of recycling takes more money than what you yield back from it, unlike a lot of the cans and bottles that actually do get recycled. So, one of the - one of the problems there is a --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Wait, say that part again.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: So essentially companies will pay to recycle "x" percent of their product, right? They'll pay more money than it costs, meaning more money than they get back in the plastic recycling, just to say that their product is recyclable.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Wow!

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: But in practice, it is not municipally recyclable, meaning you can't just toss it in the recycling bin in your town or your city and have it get recycled. People end up --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So what happens when we toss it in our recycling bin?

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: It ends up in the landfill. So, the challenge here is understanding what is municipally recyclable, what can be practically recycled, and what's just thrown away. And that thrown away component is a huge chunk of plastic. And that's, I think, what a lot of advocates are hoping that businesses will change is how we package things.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's like a massive scandal.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Huge.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: It's a huge scam

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's a scam.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They should have to label it differently.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Do you recycle? Do you separate, I should say?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you recycle.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But, I'm saying, if you're putting your toothpaste tube in the recycling and it's not actually getting recycled -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I mean - and I also would think the concern would be people think, well, it's not worth it, I'm not going to recycle at all.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: There's a point in that episode, that first episode, where I tried to recycle Taco Bell hot sauce packets.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I saw that. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: And literally what you have to do, at least in this pilot program, is you collect all your packets, you scan a QR code, you log into a thing online, you print out a mailing label, then you find a box. You put the Taco Bell sauce packets in a box.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Put the mailing label on it. Go to the post office and mail it off. It's like - I sort of joke like, you're lazy if you don't do that, but who is practically going to do that, right?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: That - is that what it means to -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Also, the freight uses energy. Come on.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: That's right, the carbon that comes out of that.So, I think the point in all of this, because it really is a forward- leaning, optimistic show is, what can advocates and companies do together to change the nature of that packaging.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the thing that I was asking you, do you separate? You separate.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So we only have one -- two bins, trash and recycling. So, not only do I separate, I go down to the recycling and I take out of the -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I put the glass and the plastic and the paper.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And it's -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And it's gross.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, I do it -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And I do it and now you're telling me it's not worth it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So we all do it. Is it worth it?

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: You know, look, to be clear, yes, look, we live in - in New York City, which has a wonderful, fantastic recycling program.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes. OK, good.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: So, if you - if you live in a place that doesn't have that type of a program, I mean, you know, the idea that it's somebody else's problem, this is something you can do with your local city council, your mayor's office, your school.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Those are - those are good things that can be done. But the larger issue is, the types of plastics, even when you see that logo at the bottom of a container, it doesn't mean that it's recyclable, practically. It just shows you the type of plastic that it is.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Interesting that you wore green today.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Come back when you're host of "The Daily Show."

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, we've got - we have to recycle guests now, so, we've got to go. You're done.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: All right, thank you. Thanks for having me. See you later.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This was fascinating.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: You are - are you up for host?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm guest hosting the week of March 13th. Tune in.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: And, you know -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Can't wait for our guest appearance on the program, Kal Penn. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Kal.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You've got to - you have to recycle, pay back. That's only fair.

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: That's right. That's right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are you really trying to get on to "The Daily Show" right now?

utterances.speaker: PENN
utterances.sentences: I appreciated the bet.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Be sure to watch "Getting Warmer with Kal Penn" on Wednesdays streaming on Bloomberg Channel and bloomberg.com.Our thanks again to Kal Penn. Up next, we want to go back to Dianne Gallagher live on a boat where they're searching for spy balloon debris. Standby for that. This (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This morning, Navy crews are working to collect the suspected spy equipment from the Chinese balloon that traveled across the United States before being shot down off the coast of South Carolina on Saturday. Officials are saying that the debris was spread over about 7 miles in the ocean. The recovery effort is expected to take days, but it's vitally important to finding out what exactly that spy balloon was doing.We want to go back to Dianne Gallagher, who is live off a shrimp boat off the Carolina coast. That's where that recovery effort is underway. Dianne, earlier, you could see the recovery effort happen in the background. What are you seeing right now?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Dianne Gallagher, live on a shrimp boat off the coast of South Carolina. Just got a call from the Coast Guard telling her not to go much further than where they are now, but monitoring that.Dianne, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The Grammys. Beyonce making history, breaking the record for the most Grammy Award wins, but still her fans claiming she got snubbed for Album of the Year.(COMMERCIAL BREAK) [08:50:35] (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Beyonce has done it, everybody. We were all here to see it and you were, too. You were a part of this. She now holds the all-time record for the most Grammy wins. So we can finally end the GOAT debate. It's done now. All right. Who's the GOAT? It's Beyonce. It's done (ph). It's not LeBron. It's not Jordan. It's not Tom Brady. It's not Mancy (ph). It's Beyonce. OK, it's done. It's officially done.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK, so - but one thing -- one thing that Beyonce can't do -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And that is defy traffic because she was stuck in traffic. Beyonce etching her name in the record books, winning her 32nd Grammy.Here is that very special moment. Look. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Because we are witnessing history tonight. Breaking the record for the most Grammy wins of all time, be upstanding and show your respect, it's "Renaissance," Beyonce.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BEYONCE
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. I'm trying not to be too emotional. And I'm trying to just receive this night.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So Beyonce, I hate to bring up the next -- look, she defied, you know, everything, but we're bringing up the negative because she didn't take home the Album of the Year. I'm sure Beyonce is OK with that. That award went to Harry Styles for his album, "Harry's House." In fact -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Look at Lizzo's (ph) face.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What'd you say?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Lizzo's face.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: With all her wins, Beyonce has never won that category.OK, so joining us now from - to talk about this night in entertainment is entertainment journalist Segun Oduolowu. Thank you for joining - thank you for joining. We appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: SEGUN ODUOLOWU, ENTERTAINMENT JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: Thank you for having me. LEMON

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: No, the -- the whole awards show - are we -- do we want - do we want to be honest or do we want to be like --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Honest.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Come on. It's not --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What do you think?

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: OK, so I will be - I -- first of all, whoever the sound engineer was for that show, fire - fire them.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: The sound was bad.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You thought?

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Like, listening to it on your TV, people came out garbled. And if I'm going to - if I'm going to watch a music awards show, at least let the music be clear. Let me hear the artist.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I never heard it.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: But I -- it didn't sound good. The Grammy's have, like, they've got some explaining to do. Like to quote Bonnie Raitt, like, let's give them something to talk about.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh, Bonnie Raitt is one of my all-time favorites. I was so happy. She was shocked, but that -

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: I - look, I love - I love her.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: I'm a fan of hers. Like I said, I use her song in my opening.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Turn down the lights. Turn down the -

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Look, Song of the Year, I would challenge anyone, did you hear the song?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: OK. And that's my point. But - but she's the only one in the category who's the only songwriter.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: So for that in itself, I give her the award and it was --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That was -

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: There's a (INAUDIBLE). This was end when -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That was her performing in memoriam.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: In memoriam.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: So, I didn't have a problem with that. But Beyonce not winning Album of the Year --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Why, Segun?

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: OK, so here -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, hold on.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Beyonce had a - I love that she had - you know, when you say she caught the spirit. In the beginning of her speech, she's like, thank you, God. And she paused, which I thought was an amazing moment. I don't know if many people like recognized that.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: She's -- no, she is a spiritual person. Like when Lizzo went up there and thanked here - or when Lizzo went up there and won the award, she thanked Beyonce for when Beyonce sang gospel.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: And how it spoke to Lizzo.My issue with what happened at the Grammy's is when the best of the best get on stage for their awards and their moment, and thank her and thank Beyonce, there's no way you cannot tell me it's not Album of the Year. That dance album redefined and brought back a genre that had been gone.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So - well, electronic.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Electronic, dance, disco, the LGBTQ plus community that she thanked for creating it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: She said for inventing the genre.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And isn't that Beyonce's whole point with her past albums is about, you know, especially women feeling self-worth and feeling -

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And what they're conditioned. And now they've grow up to what she is and now where she realizes she is.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Yes. She -- listen, they -- she's the queen for a reason. And the reason that she's a queen is she inspires. Music, as Trevor Noah said, who did a fantastic job trying to vamp as much as he could with, you know, people showing up late for traffic. But, come on.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK. All right, so, listen, we -- it is our jobs to sort of criticize and analyze.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But I will speak for Beyonce because she is a class act. Every time this happens and people are like, Beyonce should have won, she's always very classy about it, congratulating Harry Styles. I'm sure she would say, Harry, congratulations. (INAUDIBLE) out of --

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Yes, the queen rises above.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: The queen rises above.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Even if the Grammy's took the low road.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: She knows.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Everybody knows.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Yes, everybody knows.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Everybody knows.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: Everybody knows.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Segun.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: You won't break my soul. She knows what happened.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. We'll let him sing us out.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: They do.

utterances.speaker: ODUOLOWU
utterances.sentences: No. No, we won't.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We appreciate you joining us. Have a great day, everyone.CNN "NEWSROOM" starts after this break.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, we could.
